item.title: Best Credit Cards for Pet Travelers (2025)
item.description:
If you travel with your dog and aren’t using hotel credit cards, you’re leaving money on the table. Pet fees, room rates, and all those extras add up fast — but the right cards can offset most of it with points, free nights, and elite status perks.

Here’s what I use and recommend for pet travelers.

Why Hotel Cards Make Sense for Pet Owners

Most pet-friendly hotels charge $50–$150 per stay in pet fees. You can’t avoid those (yet), but you can make the room itself free by booking with points. And with elite status, you get perks like room upgrades, late checkout, and free breakfast — all of which make traveling with a dog way easier.

I haven’t paid for a hotel room in years. I use Hilton points from my credit cards, and the free night certificates cover the rest.

My Setup: The Hilton Combo

I’m loyal to Hilton because their pet policies are solid (most properties allow dogs up to 75 lbs with no breed restrictions), and their credit cards are some of the best in the game.

Hilton Honors American Express Aspire

Annual fee: $550
Status: Automatic Diamond (the top tier)
Free nights: 1 per year, plus more at $30k and $60k spend
Sign-up bonus: 175,000 points after spending $6,000 in 6 months

This is the card if you’re serious about hotel travel. Diamond status gets you room upgrades, executive lounge access, and late checkout — all super helpful when traveling with a dog.

That 175,000-point bonus alone is worth around 2–3 free nights at most Hilton properties. Combined with the annual free night certificate, you could have a week’s worth of hotel stays from day one.

Key perks:

  • Up to $400/year in Hilton resort credits ($200 every 6 months)
  • Up to $200/year in flight credits ($50/quarter)
  • Up to $209/year CLEAR credit
  • $100 credit at Waldorf Astoria and Conrad properties
  • 14x points at Hilton, 7x on dining and flights, 3x everything else

How the $550 fee pays for itself:

Perk Value
Annual free night certificate $300+
Hilton resort credits $400
Flight credits $200
CLEAR credit $209
Total $1,100+

Even if you only use half of these, you’re coming out ahead. I use the resort credits on room charges during Hilton stays and the flight credits stack up over the year without thinking about it.

Hilton Honors American Express Surpass

Annual fee: $150
Status: Automatic Gold (Diamond if you spend $40k/year)
Free nights: 1 after spending $15k in a calendar year
Sign-up bonus: 155,000 points after spending $3,000 in 6 months

This is the sweet spot for most travelers. Gold status gets you the 5th night free on award stays, plus a daily food & beverage credit or free breakfast at most properties.

The sign-up bonus is easier to hit than the Aspire ($3k vs $6k), and 155,000 points is still enough for multiple free nights.

Key perks:

  • Up to $200/year in Hilton credits ($50/quarter)
  • 12x points at Hilton, 6x on dining/groceries/gas, 3x everything else
  • Free night after $15k spend

How the $150 fee pays for itself:

Perk Value
Quarterly Hilton credits $200
Total $200

Just by using the $50 quarterly credit on any Hilton purchase (room charges, dining at the hotel, etc.), you’re $50 ahead before you even count the points you’re earning. If you hit the $15k spend for the free night certificate, that’s another $200+ in value.

I carry both the Aspire and Surpass. Between them, I get 2–3 free night certificates per year, plus enough points from everyday spending to cover several more nights.

Hilton Honors American Express (No Annual Fee)

Annual fee: $0
Status: Silver
Sign-up bonus: 100,000 points after spending $2,000 in 6 months

If you’re just getting started, this is a no-risk way to begin earning Hilton points. You won’t get a free night certificate, but you still get the 5th night free benefit on award stays, which is a 20% discount on any points redemption of 5+ nights.

100,000 points for just $2,000 in spending — with no annual fee — is one of the best entry points into hotel rewards. No fee means nothing to justify.

Key perks:

  • 7x points at Hilton, 5x on dining/groceries/gas, 3x everything else
  • No annual fee
  • 5th night free on award stays

The Alternative: Marriott

If you prefer Marriott properties, the Marriott Bonvoy Boundless card is solid.

Annual fee: $95
Status: Silver Elite (Gold at $35k spend)
Free nights: 1 per year (worth up to 35,000 points, can top off with 15k more)
Sign-up bonus: 3 free nights (each worth up to 50,000 points) after spending $3,000 in 3 months

That sign-up bonus is huge — 3 free nights at properties up to 50,000 points each. That could cover a long weekend at a solid Marriott property right out of the gate.

Key perks:

  • Up to 17x points at Marriott properties
  • 3x on dining, groceries, and gas (first $6k/year)
  • Annual free night certificate
  • 15 Elite Night Credits per year

How the $95 fee pays for itself:

Perk Value
Annual free night certificate $200+
Total $200+

The free night certificate alone is worth at least double the annual fee at most Marriott properties. You can also top it off with up to 15,000 additional points to book nicer hotels.

Marriott’s pet policies vary more by property than Hilton’s, so always check before booking. Some Marriott brands (like Residence Inn and TownePlace Suites) tend to be more consistently pet-friendly.

Which Card Should You Get?

If you’re new to points: Start with the no-annual-fee Hilton card. The 100,000-point bonus for $2,000 spend is an easy win, and you can learn the system risk-free.

If you travel 2–4 times per year: The Hilton Surpass is the move. The $150 fee is more than covered by the $200 in quarterly Hilton credits.

If you travel frequently: Get the Hilton Aspire. Yes, it’s $550 — but you get over $1,100 in credits and perks back. Diamond status is a game-changer for traveling with dogs — upgrades to suites mean more space for everyone.

If you prefer Marriott: The Boundless card is a good value at $95/year. The annual free night alone makes it worth keeping.

How I Booked Panama City Beach for Free

For my recent 5-night trip to Panama City Beach, I used:

  • Hilton points (earned from my Surpass card)
  • A free night certificate (from my Aspire card)
  • The 5th night free benefit (book 4 nights with points, get the 5th free)

Total out of pocket for the room: $0

I still paid the $125 pet fee (5+ nights), but that’s a lot easier to stomach when the room was free.

Quick Comparison

Card Annual Fee Sign-Up Bonus Credits/Perks Free Night
Hilton Aspire $550 175k points $1,100+/year Yes (annual)
Hilton Surpass $150 155k points $200/year After $15k spend
Hilton (no fee) $0 100k points — No
Marriott Boundless $95 3 free nights — Yes (annual)

The Bottom Line

Pet travel gets expensive fast. The right credit cards won’t eliminate pet fees, but they can make the room free — and that’s a huge win.

The annual fees on these cards look scary at first, but once you factor in the credits and free nights, most of them pay you back more than you put in. Start with whichever card fits your budget and travel frequency, and build from there.

I’ve been running this setup for years, and it’s saved me thousands. If you’re road tripping with your dog anyway, you might as well do it for free.

Questions about which card is right for you? Reach out — happy to help.
